title: Chinese Government provides RMB 100 million grant for the Abdulla Mzee Hospital Rehabilitation and Upgrading Project
description: On March 25, 2013, Chinese and Tanzanian government representatives signed an exchange of letters for the Abdullah Mzee Hospital Rehabilitation and Upgrading Project (or 援桑给巴尔阿卜杜拉姆才医院) in Mkoani on Pemba Island in Zanzibar. China Daily reported that the Chinese government granted 100 million RMB ($15 million USD) for this project.   The hospital is built on the site of an older one that was also funded by the Chinese government in 1970. The new hospital has 160 beds, compared with 61 at the previous one. Covering 8,000 square meters, the hospital now has an emergency building, office building and a building for patients. China IPPR International was responsible for project design and China Jiangsu Construction Engineering Group was the implementing contractor. Construction started on August 27, 2015. A formal project handover ceremony took place on on October 24, 2016. This hospital was officially inaugurated on November 26, 2016.
combined_text:
# Sector

China Daily reported that the Chinese government granted 100 million RMB ($15 million USD) for this project.   The hospital is built on the site of an older one that was also funded by the Chinese government in 1970. The new hospital has 160 beds, compared with 61 at the previous one. Covering 8,000 square meters, the hospital now has an emergency building, office building and a building for patients. China IPPR International was responsible for project design and China Jiangsu Construction Engineering Group was the implementing contractor. Construction started on August 27, 2015. A formal project handover ceremony took place on on October 24, 2016. This hospital was officially inaugurated on November 26, 2016.

title: BoT makes RMB 500 million drawdown under currency swap agreement with PBOC in 2013 (Linked to Project ID#92560 and ID#92561)
description: On December 22, 2011, Bank of Thailand (BoT) — Thailand’s central bank — and the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) signed an RMB 70 billion (THB 320 billion) bilateral currency swap agreement to facilitate trade and improve foreign currency liquidity in Thailand. Three years later, on December 22, 2014, BoT and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement and set the maximum drawing rights to RMB 70 billion (THB 370 billion). BoT and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement — with maximum drawing rights of RMB 70 billion (THB 370 billion) — again on December 22, 2017. BNM made three (gross) drawdowns under the currency swap agreement in 2013, 2015, and 2016: an RMB 500 million drawdown in 2013, an RMB 500,000,000 drawdown in 2015, and an RMB 500 million drawdown in 2016. The interest rate and maturity length that applied to these drawdowns (borrowings) are unknown. However, it is known that the proceeds from the drawdowns were used by BOT to make RMB liquidity available to financial institutions in Thailand in order to facilitate cross-border trade and investment settlements. The 2013 drawdown is captured via Project ID#92562; the 2015 drawdown is captured via Project ID#92560; and the 2016 drawdown is captured via Project ID#92561.
staff_comments: 1. A bilateral currency swap (BCS) agreement — also known as a central bank liquidity swap agreement — is an agreement between the central banks of two countries to exchange cash flows in different currencies at predetermined rates over a specified period of time. Central banks participate in these agreements to facilitate bilateral trade settlements using their national currencies (rather than relying upon on a third-party currency such as the U.S. dollar), manage demands from their local banks, and provide liquidity support to financial markets. The party that draws down on the swap line becomes the borrower and the other party becomes lender. During the term of the swap, the party that draws down on the swap line makes either fixed or floating interest payments on the principal amount. If both parties draw down on the swap line, then both parties exchange fixed or floating interest payments on the principal amounts.  The 5-step process of drawing upon a currency swap line with the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) can described from the perspective of an importer in a given country (‘Country X’) seeking to settle trade with a Chinese firm in RMB. Step 1: The central bank of Country X and the PBOC activate their currency swap in advance, at which point each party deposits a specific amount of its currency in an account controlled by the other party (i.e. the central bank of Country X deposits local currency in an account controlled by the PBOC, and the PBOC deposits an equivalent amount in RMB in an account controlled by the central bank of Country X). Step 2: A firm in Country X that imports goods from China applies for an RMB-denominated loan from a domestic bank. Step 3: The domestic bank in Country X that receives the loan application then applies to its central bank for an RMB-denominated loan. After a review process, the central bank of Country X notifies the domestic bank applicant that its loan application was approved. The central bank of Country X subsequently requests that the PBOC transfer RMB funds from the central bank of Country X’s swap account within the PBOC to the loan applicant’s account with a corresponding bank in China. Step 4:  The domestic bank in Country X directs the corresponding bank in China to transfer RMB funds into a Chinese exporter’s account, and the corresponding bank in China provides RMB funds to the Chinese exporter. Step 5: The importer in Country X repays the RMB-denominated loan at its maturity date. The domestic bank notifies the central bank of Country X of the repayment, and transfers RMB into the central bank’s account within the PBOC through the corresponding bank in China. For the central bank of Country X, the RMB deposit is an asset that should be recorded on its balance sheet as an official reserve asset denominated in RMB. The contra entry of this asset is the liability in the local currency of Country X that represents China’s claims in the central bank of Country X. This should be also recorded on the balance sheet of the central bank of Country X. At the time of the exchange of currencies, it should be recorded as an increase in assets and an increase in liabilities of the monetary authorities in the balance of payments. The reason why the PBOC uses this mechanism to provide renminbi liquidity to other central bank is to increase the speed, convenience, and volume of transactions between the two countries. More detailed information about currency swaps with the PBOC can be found at https://www.imf.org/-/media/Files/Publications/WP/2021/English/wpiea2021210-print-pdf.ashx and https://thechinaguys.com/the-rise-of-the-renminbi-the-reality-of-bilateral-swap-agreements/ and https://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/bop/2017/pdf/17-25a.pdf. 2. AidData treats drawdowns under BCS agreements with the PBOC as collateralized loans because, in a BCS arrangement, the currency of the borrower is held as collateral while the lender receives interest on the amount drawn down by the borrower until repayment is made. 3. BOT and and PBOC first signed a currency swap agreement on December 6, 2001. A series of renewal agreements ensued.4. Most central banks publish their end-of-year outstanding PBOC swap debt, but only a few report detailed transaction-level data on drawdowns during the year. Therefore, if no information on drawings is available, AidData assumes that total drawdowns during the reporting period equal the amount outstanding at the end of the reporting period (and vice versa). Since the (de jure) maturities of PBOC swap drawings are 12 months or less, this creates a lower bound estimate for actual drawdowns under the PBOC swap line. 5. PBOC swap debt is frequently rolled over. In central bank reports where one can only observe the year-end outstanding amount, no distinction between rollovers and drawdowns is possible. In these cases, one can derive (new) drawdowns as the difference between the current and last year’s outstanding swap debt stock. This measure essentially captures net lending (drawdowns) through the PBOC swap line.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
BoT makes RMB 500 million drawdown under currency swap agreement with PBOC in 2013 (Linked to Project ID#92560 and ID#92561)

# Description
On December 22, 2011, Bank of Thailand (BoT) — Thailand’s central bank — and the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) signed an RMB 70 billion (THB 320 billion) bilateral currency swap agreement to facilitate trade and improve foreign currency liquidity in Thailand. Three years later, on December 22, 2014, BoT and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement and set the maximum drawing rights to RMB 70 billion (THB 370 billion). BoT and the PBOC renewed their bilateral currency swap agreement — with maximum drawing rights of RMB 70 billion (THB 370 billion) — again on December 22, 2017. BNM made three (gross) drawdowns under the currency swap agreement in 2013, 2015, and 2016: an RMB 500 million drawdown in 2013, an RMB 500,000,000 drawdown in 2015, and an RMB 500 million drawdown in 2016. The interest rate and maturity length that applied to these drawdowns (borrowings) are unknown. However, it is known that the proceeds from the drawdowns were used by BOT to make RMB liquidity available to financial institutions in Thailand in order to facilitate cross-border trade and investment settlements. The 2013 drawdown is captured via Project ID#92562; the 2015 drawdown is captured via Project ID#92560; and the 2016 drawdown is captured via Project ID#92561.
justification: Currency swap agreement between central banks with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Bilateral currency swap agreement, RMB liquidity provision for trade and investment settlements

title: China Eximbank provides loan worth THB 11.6 billion for Chao Phraya Estate Landmark Waterfront Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#73300)
description: In 2013, China Eximbank reportedly issued a loan worth 11.6 billion baht to Landmark Holdings Company Limited — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of BCEG Thai International Co., Ltd and the MAI-listed firm Country Group Development Plc (CGD) — for the Chao Phraya Estate Landmark Waterfront Construction Project.   The purpose of this project is to construct a high-end residential and hotel project (known as the Landmark Waterfront or Chao Phraya Estate) on a prestigious waterfront address along the Chao Phraya River in the city of Bangkok. Upon completion, it will be the first luxury, 5-star hotel-managed riverside condominium in Bangkok.   The total investment in the project is 29 billion baht, of which 11.6 billion baht comes from the loan of the Export-Import Bank of China.   A groundbreaking ceremony took place on June 6, 2014. However, construction did not begin until June 19, 2014. Construction ended on or around February 13, 2018. The hotel (Four Seasons Private Residences) officially opened during the summer of 2018.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Chao Phraya Estate Project.2. On September 19, 2016, it was announced that Country Group Development and Joint Venture partner BCEG Thai International Co., Ltd would continue project financing through China Pingan Bank with a THB 13.3 billion loan and would finish the project on schedule. The loan from China Pingan Bank was to be managed through Landmark Holdings Company Limited. The China Eximbank loan is separate from the 13.3 billion baht loan issued by China Pingan Bank also for the construction of the Chao Phraya Estate in 2016 (captured in Project ID#73300).3. Beijing Construction Engineering Group International (BCEGI) reportedly holds a 30% ownership stake in Landmark Holdings Company Limited (through its subsidiary, BCEG Thai International Co., Ltd).
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China Eximbank provides loan worth THB 11.6 billion for Chao Phraya Estate Landmark Waterfront Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#73300)

# Description
In 2013, China Eximbank reportedly issued a loan worth 11.6 billion baht to Landmark Holdings Company Limited — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture of BCEG Thai International Co., Ltd and the MAI-listed firm Country Group Development Plc (CGD) — for the Chao Phraya Estate Landmark Waterfront Construction Project.   The purpose of this project is to construct a high-end residential and hotel project (known as the Landmark Waterfront or Chao Phraya Estate) on a prestigious waterfront address along the Chao Phraya River in the city of Bangkok. Upon completion, it will be the first luxury, 5-star hotel-managed riverside condominium in Bangkok.   The total investment in the project is 29 billion baht, of which 11.6 billion baht comes from the loan of the Export-Import Bank of China.   A groundbreaking ceremony took place on June 6, 2014. However, construction did not begin until June 19, 2014. Construction ended on or around February 13, 2018. The hotel (Four Seasons Private Residences) officially opened during the summer of 2018.
justification: Project is focused on luxury residential and hotel development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: High-end residential and hotel project, no mention of energy or environmental components

title: China sends agriculture experts for technology training
description: China has sent experts on agricultural machinery and equipment to Timor-Leste to conduct training in the maintenance of agricultural technology. This small pilot project ran from November 2013 to December 2014. Specifically, the project taught Timorese farmers the knowledge and skills to increase production of maize.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China sends agriculture experts for technology training

# Description
China has sent experts on agricultural machinery and equipment to Timor-Leste to conduct training in the maintenance of agricultural technology. This small pilot project ran from November 2013 to December 2014. Specifically, the project taught Timorese farmers the knowledge and skills to increase production of maize.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural training and knowledge transfer without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training in agricultural machinery maintenance and maize production techniques

title: Chinese Government provides $212,000 grant for Phase 1 of Tripartite Agricultural Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#64476)
description: At the fourth meeting of the US-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue in Beijing in May 2012, Chinese State Councillor Dai Bingguo and US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton agreed that the two countries would conduct development cooperation in agriculture, health and human resources in other nations (US Department of State 2012). This tripartite agricultural cooperation project Phase I (中美东农业技术合作项目一期) was initiated by the US and China in conjunction with the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) of Timor-Leste.   After a scoping mission conducted in February 2013 and subsequent follow-up meetings, a consensus was reached between China and the US to conduct trilateral aid cooperation on agricultural development and food security in Timor-Leste. As part of USAID’s existing ‘Developing Agricultural Communities’ program from the US side, the aim was to improve food security through improved farming practices. According to the Timor Leste Aid Management Platform, the agreement for this project was signed in October 2013. The projected value of the initiative was USD 400,000 from the Chinese side and USD 5 million from the American side. While the total actual commitment of the project from China was 212407.89 USD, the total actual disbursement from the Chinese side was 210,000 USD.  The project started on October 2013 and completed on December 2014.  This project is linked to project #64476, Phase II of the tripartite agricultural cooperation project in Timor-Leste.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides $212,000 grant for Phase 1 of Tripartite Agricultural Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#64476)

# Description
At the fourth meeting of the US-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue in Beijing in May 2012, Chinese State Councillor Dai Bingguo and US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton agreed that the two countries would conduct development cooperation in agriculture, health and human resources in other nations (US Department of State 2012). This tripartite agricultural cooperation project Phase I (中美东农业技术合作项目一期) was initiated by the US and China in conjunction with the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) of Timor-Leste.   After a scoping mission conducted in February 2013 and subsequent follow-up meetings, a consensus was reached between China and the US to conduct trilateral aid cooperation on agricultural development and food security in Timor-Leste. As part of USAID’s existing ‘Developing Agricultural Communities’ program from the US side, the aim was to improve food security through improved farming practices. According to the Timor Leste Aid Management Platform, the agreement for this project was signed in October 2013. The projected value of the initiative was USD 400,000 from the Chinese side and USD 5 million from the American side. While the total actual commitment of the project from China was 212407.89 USD, the total actual disbursement from the Chinese side was 210,000 USD.  The project started on October 2013 and completed on December 2014.  This project is linked to project #64476, Phase II of the tripartite agricultural cooperation project in Timor-Leste.
justification: Agricultural development project focused on food security and farming practices, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Tripartite agricultural cooperation project, focus on improving food security through farming practices, part of USAID's 'Developing Agricultural Communities' program

title: Chinese Government provides $2.2 million grant for Medical Team Dormitory Construction Project
description: On December 19, 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of Timor-Leste signed a grant agreement worth $2,290,207.55 for the Medical Team Dormitory Construction Project. The purpose of the project was to build a new 1,273 square meter dormitory to house Chinese medical personnel stationed at Guido Valadares National Hospital (Portuguese: Hospital Nacional Guido Valadares), which is located in the eastern part of the capital city of Dili (exact locational coordinates: 8.555663°S 125.592987°E).   Hebei Construction Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on November 11, 2014 and the project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on October 28, 2015.   According to the Government of Timor-Leste’s Aid Transparency Portal (ATP), the Chinese Government ultimately disbursed $2.2 million ($400,000 on December 31, 2014, $600,000 on March 31, 2015, $600,000 on June 30, 2015, and $600,000 on September 30, 2015) of grant funding for the project. The ATP Project Identification Number is 87292538296.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Construction of China-aided Medical Team Dormitory Project. The Chinese project title is 援东医疗队新宿舍 or 东帝汶医疗队宿舍项目. The Portuguese project title is construção de um dormitório com dois pisos, em Bidau.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $2.2 million grant for Medical Team Dormitory Construction Project

# Description
On December 19, 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of Timor-Leste signed a grant agreement worth $2,290,207.55 for the Medical Team Dormitory Construction Project. The purpose of the project was to build a new 1,273 square meter dormitory to house Chinese medical personnel stationed at Guido Valadares National Hospital (Portuguese: Hospital Nacional Guido Valadares), which is located in the eastern part of the capital city of Dili (exact locational coordinates: 8.555663°S 125.592987°E).   Hebei Construction Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on November 11, 2014 and the project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on October 28, 2015.   According to the Government of Timor-Leste’s Aid Transparency Portal (ATP), the Chinese Government ultimately disbursed $2.2 million ($400,000 on December 31, 2014, $600,000 on March 31, 2015, $600,000 on June 30, 2015, and $600,000 on September 30, 2015) of grant funding for the project. The ATP Project Identification Number is 87292538296.
justification: Project is focused on construction of medical personnel housing, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Medical Team Dormitory Construction Project, housing for Chinese medical personnel, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Bekosi Primary School Expansion Project
description: In 2013, at the request of former First Lady, Kirsty Sword Gusmao, the then Goodwill Ambassador for Education of Timor-Leste, the Chinese Embassy in Timor-Leste provided a grant for the Bekosi Primary School Expansion Project. The purpose of the project was to expand the Bekosi Primary School (Becussi Primary School) in the capital city of Dili by constructing additional 3 additional classrooms and 1 teacher's room. The expanded area of the school covered 315 square meters and was able to accommodate an additional 200 students on top of the current 300+ pupils. The opening ceremony for the expanded school was held on August 19, 2015.  Chinese Ambassador, Liu Hongyang, was in attendance and gave a speech.
staff_comments: This project is also known as Becussi Primary School Expansion Project
combined_text:

EDUCATION

The expanded area of the school covered 315 square meters and was able to accommodate an additional 200 students on top of the current 300+ pupils.
